summary: (Because I creep on the tags) your take on Crowley and Aziraphale is so hot it's solar
question: (Because I creep on the tags) your take on Crowley and Aziraphale is so hot it's solar
answer:
is this the one about crowley having been in love with azira so long he’s just so annoyed by now and aziraphale only coming to terms with his feelings now so he’s struggling to hide them?

because like, let me tell you, i totally dig this dynamic– i love the book dynamic and i adore it when crowley is a anxious little serpent that can’t get a hold of his fickle feelings and aziraphale being a little grumpy but totally calm that he has somehow fallen for the enemy whilst trying to rationalize it.

but the idea of aziraphale slowly realizing that he’s in too deep and using the “but you’re a demon therefore ______” more and more as an act of self-defense? ugh. yes. YES. and crowley getting really tired of making all of this love evident to his stubborn angel? and just overall really annoyed that he still can’t not love this utterly daft divine fool? ugh. yES.

the whole “would i lie to you” in the trailer is just such a desperate plea to be seen, for feelings to be returned. and azira just brushes it off because accepting his feelings means accepting that somewhere along the way he’s done something “wrong” and that he’s not as perfectly good as he thinks himself to be.

and that breaks my heart just as much as it mends it.

tags: kidfic is one of my favourite genres when its done well
summary: Crowley and Aziraphale being godfathers/the neighbourhood guncles/emergency backup babysitters is ideal though, I have...
body:
Crowley and Aziraphale being godfathers/the neighbourhood guncles/emergency backup babysitters is ideal though, I have decided.

These old weirdos get to interact with kiddos just forming opinions about the world, so they have less preloaded prejudices and can be talked around the weirder stuff, unlike adults, and be liked for themselves, and be subjected to the best sort of logic there is, which is that of children under ten, and not be responsible for keeping them alive and raising them 24/7 because they really have no business being that level of liable for a tiny human life.

Occasional child they can hand back to someone more competent? Perfect.

Also they’re 6000 years old so them interacting with someone who hasn’t been around a decade and couldn’t possibly have the barest concept of that span of time is hilarious. Imagine Aziraphale trying to sit through an episode of Teletubbies.

summary: Good Omens: A Concept
title: Good Omens: A Concept
body:
The show is over, or nearly over. Some people think it’s great, best adaptation to ever be made, perfectly in keeping with the book. Other people think it’s awful: horrendous! An insult to the authors, even if one of them had a hand in making it. Either way, we are wrapping up. Anathema has received the second book of prophecies (to be immediately thrown out). Adam has run off to see the circus with Dog. And Crowley and Aziraphale, well that’s the major sticking point among the fans.

Any and all inference that these two characters were in a relationship (romantic or otherwise) seemed to be completely erased. Sure, Tennant and Sheen played them as characters who were in love with one another. There were sidelong glances and loving stares. But once you remove the actors’ interpretations, you’re left with a show in which an angel and a demon were very good colleagues. They didn’t even hold hands at the climax!

If there was anything the fans of the book could agree upon, it would be how utterly terrible the relationship between these two man-shaped entities was developed in the show. Still, they are sticking it out to the end.

The final scene comes up. Crowley and Aziraphale are at the Ritz. This scene was in the trailers so the audience knows how it’s going to end. Some people minimize the window, looking for something else to watch. Others pull up their phone, scrolling through Twitter or Tumblr to see if they’re going to have to disagree with some people.

“To the world,” Crowley says.

We all know how this is going to end.

Aziraphale pauses and Michael Sheen puts the most adoring look on his face. “To the world.”

The camera starts to pull out as they clink their glasses, revealing more and more of the dining room. Some people have already clicked off the video, not wanting to watch the credits. Others have gotten up, thoroughly disappointed with the lack of clear LGBTQ+ subtext that was so present in the novel. A few watch on.

The camera pauses so that Crowley and Aziraphale are sitting far in the background. The dishes on the table go flying! Crashing to the ground. Both man-shaped entities grapple at each other, making out furiously as they roll off the table and onto the floor, leaving destruction in their wake.

The screen cuts to black. It was only a second.

The fans that are still left stare open-mouthed at the screen. Did I really just see that? They take to social media.

The viewers who checked out early think it’s another joke. There’s no way that happened. It takes them weeks to realize the truth.

Someplace far away, the directors, writers, actors, and producers are all laughing. They just reverse-queer-baited the entire audience. The natural order of things has been restored.

tags: aka I keep making those fanvids and nobody asks for it
summary:
Aziraphale/Crowley - You’re No Saint 
You're standing here like an angry guy Counting all my sins just to cross them off Saying...
caption:
Aziraphale/Crowley - You’re No Saint

You’re standing here like an angry guy
Counting all my sins just to cross them off
Saying in my tongue, we still lie to trust
And in my blood couldn’t keep you

My dear, you’re not so innocent
You’re fooling Heaven’s gates
So you won’t have to change
You’re no saint, you’re no saint, yeah
